item.title: A Look Inside the Tactics of Definers, Facebook’s Attack Dog
item.media:description: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, testifying in September before a Senate committee.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: The opposition research firm had focused on the internet company’s competition. But ahead of a Senate hearing it had a new target: senators.
item.dc:creator: JACK NICAS and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg Defends Facebook as Furor Over Its Tactics Grows
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg fielded questions from reporters on Thursday about his and Sheryl Sandberg’s management of Facebook.
item.description: Mr. Zuckerberg said that he wouldn’t step down as chairman and that his No. 2, Sheryl Sandberg, was “doing great work” despite questions about their management.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG, MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MIKE ISAAC
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Google Cloud Executive Who Sought Pentagon Contract Steps Down
item.media:description: Diane Greene, a co-founder and former chief executive of VMware, was hired in 2015 to expand Google’s cloud computing business.
item.media:credit: Damien Maloney for The New York Times
item.description: Diane Greene, who has run Google Cloud for three years, will be replaced by a former Oracle executive.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: Bits: The Week in Tech: Amazon Finally Makes an HQ2 Decision
item.media:description: Amazon chose the Long Island City neighborhood of Queens as the location for half of its second headquarters. In doing so, it will have to deal with the labor, media and electoral politics of New York.
item.description: The internet retailer took 14 months to decide on a second headquarters. Surprise! There will be two of them, and skeptics have plenty to chew on.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WEISE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: From Encyclopedic Collector to ‘Wikipedian-at-Large’
item.media:description: Mike Dickison, New Zealand’s first Wikipedian-at-Large, in the library of the Auckland War Memorial Museum. “If I find something I’m passionate about, I need to share it and get other people involved too,” he said.
item.media:credit: Cornell Tukiri for The New York Times
item.description: Mike Dickison was a museum curator when he turned to another form of curating, teaching fellow New Zealanders how to beef up their country’s presence on the website.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Real Estate Technology: Try, Try Again
item.description: Stackable apartments. Robotic valets. Infrared spas. The future has arrived, haltingly, and this time will be different. Maybe.
item.dc:creator: STEFANOS CHEN

item.title: ‘No Morals’: Advertisers React to Facebook Report
item.media:description: One senior adviser in advertising suggested that Facebook should establish an ombudsman role to assess and report on its societal risks in regular financial filings.
item.description: Several top marketers were critical of the tech giant after The New York Times reported how it ignored and hid warning signs that it was being exploited to disrupt elections and spread toxic content.
item.dc:creator: SAPNA MAHESHWARI

item.title: What Amazon’s HQ2 Winners Look Like, Before Amazon
item.media:credit: Hector Emanuel for The New York Times
item.description: Crystal City in Virginia and Long Island City in Queens are about to become home to an internet giant. They will probably never appear the same again.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER LEE and HECTOR EMANUEL

item.title: Neo-Nazis Have No First Amendment Right to Harassment, Judge Rules
item.media:description: Tanya Gersh of Whitefish, Mont., became the target of a neo-Nazi “troll storm” of online harassment orchestrated by The Daily Stormer.
item.media:credit: Dan Chung/Southern Poverty Law Center, via Associated Press
item.description: A lawsuit against the publisher of the website Daily Stormer for unleashing an online “terror campaign” against a Jewish realtor can proceed.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: ‘I Don’t Really Want to Work for Facebook.’ So Say Some Computer Science Students.
item.media:description: The Cal Hacks 5.0 competition drew students to the University of California, Berkeley, including, from left, Haitao Zhang, Ingrid Wu and Emily Hu, all students at Berkeley. Some students at the hackathon expressed a reluctance to work for big tech firms.
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.description: A job at Facebook is plum. But at a recent university hackathon, some young engineers showed a changing attitude toward working at the social network.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: At War: Are Killer Robots the Future of War? Parsing the Facts on Autonomous Weapons
item.media:description: Milrem Robotic’s Tracked Hybrid Modular Infantry System at the Changi exhibition centre in Singapore in February 2016.
item.description: Under what circumstances should militaries delegate the decision to take a human life to machines? It’s a moral leap that the international community is grappling with.
item.dc:creator: KELSEY D. ATHERTON
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Minister in Charge of Japan’s Cybersecurity Says He Has Never Used a Computer
item.media:description: Yoshitaka Sakurada, left, who heads the Japanese government’s cybersecurity office, said he had no need to learn to use a computer.
item.description: Yoshitaka Sakurada appeared not to know what a USB drive was, and told lawmakers that when it was necessary to use a computer, “I order my employees or secretaries” to do it.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Facebook Cuts Ties With Washington Firm That Sought to Discredit Social Network’s Critics
item.media:description: A Facebook logo reflected on an advertisement board outside the United States Capitol in Washington in October. Facebook had initially hired Definers Public Affairs, a consulting firm, to monitor news about the social network.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: The social network faced scrutiny for working with the consulting firm, which tried to discredit critics and rivals of the Silicon Valley giant.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and JACK NICAS

item.title: Damage Control at Facebook: 6 Takeaways From The Times’s Investigation
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg at a congressional hearing in April.
item.description: An investigation by The New York Times revealed how Facebook fought back against critics during a flood of crises — with delays, denials and an influence campaign in Washington.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Tech We’re Using: The Essentials for Covering Silicon Valley: Burner Phones and Doorbells
item.media:description: The New York Times reporter Jack Nicas in San Francisco. Some of his most reliable reporting tools are a pen and paper, he says.
item.media:credit: Jim McAuley for The New York Times
item.description: Reporting on secretive technology companies sometimes means finding people who don’t want to be found. Jack Nicas, who covers Apple, relies on some old-school methods.
item.dc:creator: JACK NICAS

item.title: Amazon’s HQ2 in Virginia Leaves a Real Estate Firm Poised to Cash In
item.media:description: The Galvan, a JBG Smith property in Rockville, Md. Amazon’s expansion plans in Northern Virginia will be a windfall for the real estate company.
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.description: JBG Smith is the largest landowner in a Virginia area some have called a ghost town. That could change fast with Amazon’s new office plans.
item.dc:creator: JULIE CRESWELL

item.title: Delay, Deny and Deflect: How Facebook’s Leaders Fought Through Crisis
item.media:description: Facebook has gone on the attack as one scandal after another — Russian meddling, data sharing, hate speech — has led to a congressional and consumer backlash.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Russian meddling, data sharing, hate speech — the social network faced one scandal after another. This is how Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg responded.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL, NICHOLAS CONFESSORE, CECILIA KANG, MATTHEW ROSENBERG and JACK NICAS
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Uber’s Losses Continue Ahead of Initial Public Offering
item.media:description: Uber is preparing for an initial public offering next year, in what would likely be one of the biggest technology offerings.
item.description: Uber, which is moving toward a public debut next year, said its net loss was more than $1 billion in the third quarter.
item.dc:creator: KATE CONGER

item.title: Tech Fix: What’s Hot (and What’s Not) This Black Friday
item.media:description: The line outside a Best Buy store before it opened on Black Friday in Overland Park, Kan., last year.
item.description: To help shoppers get started, here’s a cheat sheet of the products to track, and the ones to ignore.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: New York Is a Genuine Tech Hub (and That Was Before Amazon)
item.description: The Bay Area in California remains the nation’s high-tech epicenter. But New York’s tech work force has been growing impressively.
item.dc:creator: STEVE LOHR

item.title: Amazon’s New York Home Qualifies as ‘Distressed’ Under Federal Tax Law
item.media:description: Several areas of Long Island City have been designated as federal “opportunity zones.” The one that includes Amazon’s site was attracting development even before the tax incentive.
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.description: The Long Island City site was designated as an “opportunity zone,” an incentive created by President Trump’s tax bill to help low-income areas attract investment.
item.dc:creator: JIM TANKERSLEY

item.title: Amazon HQ2: How New York and Virginia Won the Beauty Contest
item.media:description: Amazon will take about one million square feet in Long Island City, Queens.
item.media:credit: Stefano Ukmar for The New York Times
item.description: Eager candidates offered name changes, helipads and even cactuses to entice the company into setting up shop.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: State of the Art: How Google Photos Became a Perfect Jukebox for Our Memories
item.description: Google Photos, introduced in 2015, has become one of the most emotionally resonant pieces of technology today. It is also shaping our narratives along the way.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Up Next: A Tech Wunderkind Who Knows Jaden Smith and Elon Musk
item.media:description: Iddris Sandu wants to “level the playing field” between Silicon Valley and communities of color.
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.description: Iddris Sandu has written code for Instagram and Twitter, and counts Barack Obama as a fan.
item.dc:creator: ALEX HAWGOOD

item.title: A $2 Billion Question: Did New York and Virginia Overpay for Amazon?
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York looked on as Mayor Bill de Blasio shook hands Tuesday with John Schoettler, an Amazon executive. The state will give the company more than $1.5 billion in incentives to locate an operation in Long Island City, Queens, and hire 25,000 workers.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: The states offered tax credits, rebates and other incentives to lure the online retail giant and 25,000 jobs. Neighboring states offered even more.
item.dc:creator: BEN CASSELMAN

item.title: Dominating Retail? Yes. Reviving a City? No Thanks.
item.media:description: A demonstration in front of Amazon in Seattle in April. Protesters called for a tax on the city’s largest companies to help pay for homeless services. The tax passed, but Amazon fought the measure, and the Seattle City Council repealed it.
item.description: Amazon is not in the business of saving your hometown.
item.dc:creator: EMILY BADGER

item.title: How to Tell if Those Black Friday Deals Are Actually Worth Buying
item.media:description: This Black Friday, keep an eye out for deals on small appliances and electronics, like crock pots and the Instant Pot, Wirecutter experts said.
item.media:credit: Courtney Sacco/Caller-Times, via Corpus Christi Caller-Times, via Associated Press
item.description: Black Friday and Cyber Monday mean hundreds of online deals, discounts, and in-person doorbusters, but these tips will help you tell which ones are really worth your money.
item.dc:creator: ALAN HENRY

item.title: Barry Rand, Barrier-Breaking Chief Executive, Is Dead at 74
item.media:description: Barry Rand, one of few African-Americans to become chief executive of a Fortune 500 company, in 2012.
item.description: After being passed over at Xerox, he became one of the few African-American chief executives of a Fortune 500 company when he took control of Avis.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

item.title: Online Photo Printing for the Holidays (and Any Time)
item.description: Want to share photos this holiday season (and other times)? We have recommendations for cards, photo books, and photo printing services.
item.dc:creator: WIRECUTTER STAFF

item.title: Tavares Strachan Teams With SpaceX to Launch Satellite-Sculpture Into Orbit
item.media:description: A digital rendering of the “Enoch” satellite.
item.description: The object, made of 24-karat gold, honors Robert Henry Lawrence Jr., the first African-American to train as an astronaut.
item.dc:creator: JORI FINKEL
item.category: Los Angeles County Museum of Art

item.title: Before a Deal, Amazon Had to Know: Could Cuomo and De Blasio Get Along?
item.media:description: A former General Services Administration building is surrounded by residential and office high-rises in the Crystal City neighborhood of Arlington, Va.
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.description: After meeting with the governor and mayor, Amazon decided the men could put aside their differences, and it began to iron out a package worth over a billion dollars.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WEISE and J. DAVID GOODMAN

item.title: For University of Minnesota, Chinese Tycoon’s Arrest Shines Light, Again, on Sexual Assault
item.media:description: Richard Liu, the founder and chief of JD.com, in 2016. Mr. Liu, who has denied wrongdoing, was in Minnesota for a global business program, aimed at Asian executives, that is on track to generate over $10 million in tuition since starting last year.
item.description: The billionaire Richard Liu, who has denied wrongdoing, was in Minneapolis attending a relatively new and lucrative academic program when he was arrested.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY HSU, RAYMOND ZHONG and CAROLYN ZHANG

item.title: At War: The U.S. Army Is Trying to Develop New Land Mines — Ones That Don’t Harm Civilians
item.media:description: A mine-clearing line charge being detonated during live-fire training at Fort Irwin in California, October 2016.
item.description: The Army has been working on a new model of antivehicle mines that could reduce the threat posed to civilians, if it works the way the service hopes.
item.dc:creator: JOHN ISMAY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Facebook Failed to Police How Its Partners Handled User Data
item.media:description: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee in September. Ron Wyden, a committee member, has pressed the company on its data privacy protections.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: For years, Facebook struck deals that gave device makers access to troves of user data. A disclosure to Congress details the company’s lax oversight of those partnerships.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE, MICHAEL LaFORGIA and GABRIEL J.X. DANCE

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Amazon’s HQ2 Will Benefit From New York City. But What Does New York Get?
item.media:description: The waterfront in Long Island City, Queens, a neighborhood Amazon will announce as a site for one of its HQ2 complexes.
item.description: Amazon promises tens of thousands of new jobs, but should we expect more than that?
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: Amazon’s New Neighbor: The Nation’s Largest Housing Project
item.media:description: The Queensbridge Houses, the nation’s largest public housing complex, is home to a mostly black and Hispanic population with a median household income well below the federal poverty level.
item.description: As a company owned by the world’s richest man prepares to transform Long Island City, tenants of the Queensbridge Houses worry that they’ll be left behind.
item.dc:creator: COREY KILGANNON

item.title: Are You Ready for the Nanoinfluencers?
item.media:description: Images of #sponsored content from the Instagram accounts of Alexis Baker, top row, and Haley Stutzman. Ms. Baker has about 2,600 followers and Ms. Stutzman about 5,500.
item.media:credit: Top row, Alexis Baker; bottom row, Haley Stutzman
item.description: Influencers are so 2014. And microinfluencers are so last week. Now advertisers see value in people with as few as 1,000 followers: the nanoinfluencers.
item.dc:creator: SAPNA MAHESHWARI

item.title: Alibaba’s Singles Day Sales Top $30 Billion. The Party May Not Last.
item.media:description: Alibaba’s sales on Singles Day, which gets its name from the date, Nov. 11, broke the 200 billion yuan, or $28.8 billion, mark near the end of the 24-hour shopping event on Sunday.
item.description: China’s slowing economic growth and weakening consumer sentiment pose a challenge to an e-commerce giant with world-swallowing ambitions.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG
